sections.text:
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 127, 111803 (2021)]
Nicole F. Bell, Giorgio Busoni, Theo F. Motta, Sandra Robles , Anthony W. Thomas, and Michael Virgato
(Received 13 October 2022; published 30 November 2022)
DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevLett.129.239902
The results presented in our published Letter used an incorrect expression for the hadronic form factor. Here we revise Eq. (10) and Figs. 2 and 3 to use the preferred dipole form. The significance of the hadronic form factor suppression is increased, by up to an order of magnitude. The qualitative conclusions of the Letter are unchanged. The replacement for Eq. (10), the relationship between the squared nucleon coupling at zero and finite momentum, is

We see that as expected, the normalized spectrum of the interaction rate is narrower and peaks towards slightly lower energy transfer. The effect of this additional suppression on the capture rates is shown in Fig. 3. When including the momentum dependence of the neutron couplings, Eq. (10), in the free Fermi gas approach (magenta line), the capture rate for dark matter (DM) of mass mχ ≳ 1 GeV is now reduced by more than 2 orders of magnitude (pseudoscalar operator) for the 1.5 M⊙ neutron star (NS) (middle column) and more than 3 orders of magnitude for the heaviest NS considered here (compare dashed dark blue with orange lines). When accounting for this correction in the interacting baryon approach (magenta line), we find that the largest suppression of the capture rate
